user_request: A poem where the speaker compares a lover to a summer day but concludes the beloved outlasts it.

revision_history.draft:
the metallic tang of heat  
the porch creaks / its bones dry as parchment  
the smell of rain after a dry spell  
fades into the dust of August  

your skin holds the scent of rain  
after a dry spell—  
a whisper of moss  
between your collarbones  
your fingers, a map of  
unspoken constellations  
tracing the arc of a wrist  
that never quite bends  

you are the crease in the shirt  
that never fades, the hum  
of a refrigerator  
humming in the dark—something  
that outlives the season’s  
slow unraveling  
a scent lingering  
where the cicadas stopped singing

the metallic tang of heat  
the porch groans—its ribs brittle as parchment  
the scent of rain after a dry spell  
dissolves into August’s dust  

your skin cradles the ghost of rain  
after a dry spell—  
a mossy hush  
between your collarbones  
your fingers, a chart of  
unspoken constellations  
tracing the arc of a wrist  
that resists the bend  

you are the fold in the shirt  
that refuses to fade, the murmur  
of a refrigerator  
humming in the dark—something  
that outlives the season’s  
slow unraveling  
a scent etched  
where the cicadas stopped singing

final_poem:
the metallic tang of heat  
the porch groans—its ribs brittle as parchment  
the scent of rain after a dry spell  
dissolves into August’s dust  

your skin cradles the ghost of rain  
after a dry spell—  
a mossy hush  
between your collarbones  
your fingers, a chart of  
unspoken constellations  
tracing the arc of a wrist  
that resists the bend  

you are the fold in the shirt  
that refuses to fade, the murmur  
of a refrigerator  
humming in the dark—something  
that outlives the season’s  
slow unraveling  
a scent etched  
where the cicadas ceased their song
